text:
<@U032D0T39QR> I'm sorry you had this happen - it's so frustrating and yet oh so common in the industry.
There are some great courses out there (and <http://learningseo.io|learningseo.io> includes some brilliant stuff, including lots and lots of free courses, classes and guides from all over the internet) but if you feel you need a certificate to prove your learnings then I recommend the Blue Array course. It's £495 for the SEO Manager course and I know a lot of people have really enjoyed it.
To me, it does sound like what you said, like the SEO Director wants you to do part of his job, which is ridiculous! But sadly all to common for those who aren't men in the indsutry.
Do let me know if you'd like any more tips, more than happy to help]

text: Thank you Natalie! When i see the idea of a £500 investment to be an SEO manager and I  have no desire to be that I think jesus cant i just be something else adjacent and still learn whaat i need to know. its not like SEO managers know how to do what i do.

elements.text: Thank you Natalie! When i see the idea of a £500 investment to be an SEO manager and I  have no desire to be that I think jesus cant i just be something else adjacent and still learn whaat i need to know. its not like SEO managers know how to do what i do.

text: <@U032D0T39QR> your assessment that the SEO director wanted you to be able to do his job is probably not far off the mark. IMHO it’s totally unnecessary for a content director to know everything about SEO, especially with an SEO director on the team! I’m very curious about why a company would prioritize that specific thing when they already have a leader in that role, presumably managing a team of people who are also experts in that thing. Was it emphasized heavily in the job description?

elements.text: your assessment that the SEO director wanted you to be able to do his job is probably not far off the mark. Was it emphasized heavily in the job description?

text: I am not sure anymore but he was my last interview and before him, it was looking like it was going to be mine. He wanted to make it clear to me that he didn’t have any set SEO guidelines and that we would come up with them together. He was meeting with me to see if I would work with him the way he worked with the current director who said I was a great fit. He said they came up with things together in meetings. I thought it was weird. His final words seemed like he wasn’t going to recommend me. He said he was going to ‘gather his notes’.

text: a lot of roles ask for SEO skills. I never know what SEO skills means really. keyword search? using a tool? i mean i know that stuff but …

text:
Hey <@UUH2C52DQ>. I have been using a content workflow management tool called <https://narrato.io/|Narrato Workspace>.

It helps with most of the things you've mentioned. I use it to create content, save my files and deliver to clients. There are resources on their blog that give you an idea of how the platform works

It's pretty convenient. I don't need to use Gdocs or Drive anymore. They are upgrading features frequently so it'll probably get better with time.

I signed up about 4 months ago and they had an offer of 6-months free access. Not sure if the offer is still there, but it's worth checking out.

attachments.fallback: Narrato WorkSpace - Content Creation & Workflow Software
attachments.text: Narrato Workspace is a content creation, collaboration, workflow and project management tool that brings all your content processes and people on a single platform.
attachments.title: Narrato WorkSpace - Content Creation & Workflow Software
